Title:
Geographic variation in the acoustic traits of greater
horseshoe bats (Rhinolophus ferrumequinum, Chiroptera): testing the
importance of drift and ecological selection in evolutionary
processes
Keywords:
acoustic variation, genetic variation, ecological
selection, cultural drift, Chiroptera, evolutionary process.
Abstract:
Patterns of intraspecific geographic variation of
signaling systems provide insight into evolutionary processes driving
phenotypic divergence. The acoustic signals of bats are sensitive to
diverse evolutionary forces, but processes that shape geographic
variation are largely unexplored. In China, Rhinolophus ferrumequinum
displays a diverse call frequency. We quantified geographic variation in
the resting frequency (RF) of echolocation calls, and estimated genetic
structure and phylogeny of R. ferrumequinum populations. We tested three
hypotheses to explain acoustic variation: local adaptation, genetic
drift and cultural drift. Our results demonstrated significant regional
divergence in frequency and phylogeny among bat populations in northeast
(NE), central-east (CE) and southwest (SW) China. Genetic distance was
not correlated with RF variation. CE had higher frequencies than NE and
SW. Drivers of RF divergence were estimated in the SW/CE and the CE/NE
regions according to their RF divergence and genetic subdivision. In
SW/CE, RF divergence was highly correlated with geographic and
microsatellite distances, but not mitochondrial DNA distance. In CE/NE,
RF divergence was correlated with geographic and mean annual temperature
distances. We propose that when call divergence factors are estimated,
processes shaping genetic subdivision should be considered as different
drivers may change during the evolutionary process.
